title: New release 0.6.0
feat: update quinn and rustls
Fix: typos
feat(ci): Add minimal crates version check
body: Also does a bunch of simplifying of existing jobs, grouping them differently and using caching to get faster runs

title: fix: Call wait_idle on endpoint drop to allow for time for the close …
feat: add AsRef and into_inner for RpcClient and RpcServer
Interaction pattern refactor
body:
This also removes the requirement for [GATs](https://blog.rust-lang.org/2022/10/28/gats-stabilization.html) in rust stable, so we can support older rust versions.

Adds a step to CI to make sure we comply with the MSRV.

title: feat: add dummy endpoint
body:
This is useful when you want an optional endpoint.

Also add Debug instances all over the place.

title: docs: Add some more text to the readme about why this thing exists
ref: Rename main structs not conflict with trait names
body:
This is certainly opinionated, and I will only be a little sad if we
don't decide to do this.  It changes the names of the ServerChannel
and ClientChannel to include the type.  Crucially the types now have
different names than the traits they implement.

This was already done at the
transport mod.rs for ChannelTypes, kind of showing this is generally
not bad.  It is also how I've seen most Rust code.

It is a bit more verbose for writing, but this does help (me) a lot
while reading the code, which is what counts.

title: perf: avoid copying data when receiving full frames
body:
avoid a copy for the very common case that 1 arriving chunk = 1 frame, by trying to deserialize directly from the arriving Bytes buffer.

Implements https://github.com/n0-computer/quic-rpc/issues/27

title: fix: add additional framing to messages
body:
On write, prepend a u32 containing the size of the message.
On read, read until you have enough data, then deserialize.

With this we no longer rely on 1 http2 frame = 1 msg. We might as well allow http1 now...

title: fix(http2): don't log normal occurrences as errors
body: When a request is complete, the flume channel will be droppped. When a request is aborted from the client side, you will get a network error. Neither of these cases warrant logging with error level.

title: feat: Expose local address of ServerChannel
body: This adds the ability to expose the local address the ServerChannel is bound to.  This allows binding to wildcard ports and still knowing which address is used.

title: feature: make channels configurable
body:
For now only allow max frame size to be configurable. There will be more.

Also set the default to the highest possible value. The rationale being that it is preferable to waste a bit of memory by default over things not working.

tcp nodelay is not in the config because it is not relevant for all channels, just tcp channels.

title: Better oversized packet handling
feat: Add minimal tracing support
feat(http2): Shut down the hyper server on drop.
body:
This will terminate the hyper server when the ServerChannel is
dropped.  Previously it kept running in a task.

Closes #14

title: Add optional http2 channel implemented using hyper
body: This has a huge speed advantage for throughput tasks, but higher latency.

title: Allow lazy clients
body:
The API is not quite finished yet, but the basic functionality should be there.

This leaves most of the issues like how to establish an insecure quinn connection, backoff, etc. to the caller.

title: feat: improve macro for splitting crates and generate client
body:
It is often useful to have the RPC types in a seperate crate, so that a client-only usage does not have to import the server implemenation.

This makes this possible while keeping the macros to reduce boilerplate.

The generation of the dispatch function is made optional, and moved into a *generated macro*. This allows to only create the dispatch function in the *server* part, while the *client* part only uses the generated types.

The macro example is updated accordingly. A new *split* example demonstrates the full client-server usage flow over quic.

title: feat: add optional macros to reduce boilerplate
body:
Copied from https://github.com/n0-computer/quic-rpc/pull/1 :

I digged out some macro_rules code for RPC interface declarations that I wrote for an RPC experiment a while back. It was quite straightforward to adapt to quic-rpc, combined it with the request_enum macro from examples/store.rs and then got lost a bit and made the store example work.

The macros are completely optional. They also do not introduce any traits, because async traits would require boxing the futures, and so far quic-rpc works without, which is nice.

All idents have to be passed in the macro call. I think that's a feature because less magic. The invocation of derive_rpc_service! in examples/macro.rs quite literally creates the code that can be seen in examples/store.rs.

title: feat: add optional macros to reduce boilerplate
body:
I digged out some macro_rules code for RPC interface declarations that I wrote for an RPC experiment a while back. It was quite straightforward to adapt to quic-rpc, combined it with the `request_enum` macro from `examples/store.rs` and then got lost a bit and made the `store` example work.

The macros are completely optional. They also do not introduce any traits, because async traits would require boxing the futures, and so far `quic-rpc` works without, which is nice.

All idents have to be passed in the macro call. I think that's a feature because less magic. The invocation of `derive_rpc_service!` in `examples/macro.rs`  quite literally creates the code that can be seen in `examples/store.rs`.
